author: PA News Agency
title: Woman believed to be held hostage in Gaza declared dead | Ham & High
text: A hard-hit Israeli kibbutz has announced the death of Judih Weinstein â€” an American-Canadian-Israeli woman who had been thought to be held hostage in Gaza. The news came six days after Ms Weinsteinâ€™s husband, Gad Haggai, was also declared dead. Ms Weinstein, 70, and Mr Haggai, 73, were taking an early morning walk near their home in Kibbutz Nir Oz on the morning of October 7 when Hamas militants burst across the border into Israel, killing about 1,200 people and kidnapping 240 others. In the early hours of the morning, Ms Weinstein was able to call emergency services and let them know that both she and her husband had been shot and send a message to her family. Ms Weinstein and her husband had been thought to be among the hostages still held in captivity in Gaza. But six days ago, the kibbutz announced that Mr Haggai was killed on October 7 and his body was taken to Gaza. On Thursday, the kibbutz said it had learned that Ms Weinstein was also killed on October 7 and her body is also being held in Gaza. It was not immediately clear how Israeli authorities determined their deaths. The couple are survived by two sons and two daughters and seven grandchildren, the kibbutz said. US President Joe Biden said he was â€œdevastatedâ€ to learn of Ms Weinsteinâ€™s death, especially after hearing about the couple during a meeting with their daughter. The families â€œhave been living through hell for weeks. No family should have to endure such an ordealâ€, he said in a statement. Ms Weinstein was born in New York and was an active member of Kibbutz Nir Oz, a small community near the Gaza border where she taught English to children with special needs. The kibbutz said she also taught meditation techniques to children and teenagers who suffered from anxiety as a result of rocket fire from Gaza. Mr Haggai was a retired chef and jazz musician. â€œJudy dedicated her life to serving others, spending years teaching English and using her passions for poetry, puppeteering, and mindfulness to empower children of all backgrounds,â€ her family said in a statement. In a YouTube video made during a brief round of fighting between Israel and the Islamic Jihad militant group last May, Ms Weinstein read a series of poems and expressed hope for better days ahead. â€œI truly hope that the next time Iâ€™m recording some Haiku it wonâ€™t be under duress, under rocket fire, under conditions where people are at war,â€ she said. â€œMay we all be granted the right to our basic rights of home, food, shelter and peaceful days. Hereâ€™s hoping.â€ Al Haggai, one of the coupleâ€™s sons, told Israelâ€™s Channel 13 that the family had originally hoped their motherâ€™s multiple citizenships would allow her to be released during the week-long ceasefire in late November, when 105 hostages were let go. Almost all were women and children. He said that when his motherâ€™s name was not on any of the daily lists, he started to suspect that something had happened to her. According to Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahuâ€™s office, at least 23 of the approximately 129 hostages believed to be held in Gaza have either died or been killed in captivity. Nir Oz was one of the hardest-hit Israeli communities on October 7, with roughly a quarter of its residents killed or kidnapped. The families of missing hostages have drawn widespread support and sympathy in Israel as they press the government to reach a new ceasefire deal to bring home their loved ones. Mr Netanyahu met on Thursday in Tel Aviv with some of the families, where he told them there were behind-the-scene efforts to bring the hostages home, according to a statement from his office. â€œI canâ€™t elaborate on the details, we are working to return everyone,â€ he said.

author: Saint Bryan
title: Celebrating 70 years as America's favorite sports car, the Corvette gets its own exhibit at LeMay-America's Car Museum
text:
TACOMA, Wash. â€” There is beauty within the beast. For 70 years the Chevrolet Corvette has been the quintessential American sports car. At
LeMay-America's Car Museum, the milestone is celebrated in a new exhibit, â€œCorvette Creativity â€“ An Automotive Canvas.â€
"From an American design standpoint, the Corvette is leading edge," Museum executive director Gary Yamamoto said.
Sales were slipping for Chevy when the first Corvette was introduced in 1953.
"One of the principles decided he wanted to develop a sports car," Yamamoto said. "People loved the look but didn't like the performance because it had a V6 engine it, so in '57 they put in a V8 and then interest skyrocketed."
Across eight design generations the 'Vette has continued to evolve, without ever losing its cool factor. It's always looked fast and has always been fast.
"You don't have to be a car enthusiast to appreciate a Corvette," Yamamoto said.
This exhibit is made up of cars owned by Northwest collectors and pays special attention to the way they have modified their Corvettes.
"It can be something as basic as a really beautiful color," Yamamoto said.
Or it can be something like the recently installed titanium exhaust on a bespoke Corvette owned by team behind Seattle vloggers
Supercar Driven. This has to be heard to be believed.
There are also rare, one of a kind Corvettes including a racecar that once belonged to "Home Improvement's" Tim Allen. There's also one called the Black Rose.
"In some lights you look at it and it's deep burgundy and then you shift the corner and it turns black," Yamamoto said.
There's just something about a Corvette that inspires excitement
"It really has that elegant look but also sparks sports car growl," Yamamoto said.
And don't forget horsepower
"The new E Corvette can go zero to 60 in 2.5 seconds so that's fast," Yamamoto said.
â€œCorvette Creativityâ€“ An Automotive Canvas " runs through March 2024 at LeMay-America's Car Museum, which is located on East D Street in Tacoma. The museum is open every day but Tuesday and Wednesday.

title: El "Pablo Escobar de los veganos": Â¿QuiÃ©n es Bilbo Bassaterra, que vandalizÃ³ la casa de Lionel Messi?
text:
â€œEco-terroristaâ€, â€œ El Pablo Escobar de los veganos â€ y â€œDirector de una organizaciÃ³n criminalâ€. AsÃ­ se autodefine irÃ³nicamente Bilbo Bassaterra , uno de los tres hombres que fueron identificados como los responsables de vandalizar la casa de Lionel Messi como parte de una acciÃ³n de reclamo por medidas climÃ¡ticas. El joven de 31 aÃ±os es oriundo de Cadiz y es licenciado en Derecho en la Universidad de la ciudad espaÃ±ola. Se proclama animalista y vegano y desde hace tiempo forma parte del grupo de activistas ambientales Futuro Vegetal, una organizaciÃ³n que -segÃºn lo que proclama es sus redes- â€œlucha contra la crisis climÃ¡tica a travÃ©s de la desobediencia civil, el sabotaje y la acciÃ³n directa no violentaâ€.
Tras arrojar pintura roja y negra en algunas paredes de la mansiÃ³n en el marco de una denuncia sobre la â€œresponsabilidad de los ricosâ€ en la crisis climÃ¡tica (un hecho que provocÃ³ incluso la reacciÃ³n del presidente Javier Milei ), Bassaterra asegurÃ³ que â€œMessi forma parte de un porcentaje de la poblaciÃ³n que tiene una vida muy insostenible en tÃ©rminos climÃ¡ticosâ€.
Lee tambiÃ©n: Milei acusa a "comunistas" de vandalizar la casa de Messi; pide a SÃ¡nchez garantizar seguridad de argentinos en EspaÃ±a
En una entrevista que dio este miÃ©rcoles con Radio Mitre , el hombre de 31 aÃ±os considerÃ³ que lo que hicieron Ã©l y sus dos compaÃ±eros en la propiedad del astro argentino no fue un acto vandÃ¡lico, sino que se estÃ¡ â€œhaciendo ejercicio del derecho a la protestaâ€. â€œEsto tiene una motivaciÃ³n polÃ­tica y se hace para llamar la atenciÃ³n. Al ser esto, las Naciones Unidas reconocen que no se trata de vandalismoâ€, explicÃ³.
â€œAspiramos a que se promocione un cambio en el sistema agroalimentario , con dietas basadas en vegetalesâ€, prosiguiÃ³ en su relato. El ambientalista justificÃ³ que con este tipo de acciones â€œno se destruye nada, sino que se utiliza pintura lavable que con un chorro de manguera se quitaâ€.
ðŸ’¥ ACTUAMOS ðŸ’¥
Nos enseÃ±an que los poderosos son intocables. Es cierto que la polÃ­ticas se redactan e interpretan al servicio de quienes mÃ¡s tienen, atentando directamente contra los derechos del resto de la poblaciÃ³n. Pero solo son el 1%. pic.twitter.com/wV1kFl03Xc
â€” FuturoVegetalðŸ’ (@FuturoVegetal) August 6, 2024 Esta no fue la primera oportunidad en la que Futuro Vegetal, la organizaciÃ³n de la que el espaÃ±ol forma parte, realizÃ³ una medida de este estilo. Una de las mÃ¡s reconocidas fue 2022, cuando pegaron sus manos con goma a los marcos de pinturas del pintor espaÃ±ol Francisco de Goya en el Museo del Prado , en Madrid.
Lee tambiÃ©n: Activistas climÃ¡ticos pintan de rojo y negro mansiÃ³n de Messi en Ibiza
El aÃ±o pasado tambiÃ©n tiraron pintura a un millonario yate en Ibiza que supuestamente pertenecÃ­a a Nancy Walton Laurie, la multimillonaria heredera del gigante comercial estadounidense Walmart. En esa oportunidad, la policÃ­a espaÃ±ola dijo que habÃ­a detenido a 22 miembros de la organizaciÃ³n, incluyendo a los dos que participaron en la protesta del Prado y a los tres principales dirigentes del grupo.
*El Grupo de Diarios AmÃ©rica (GDA), al cual pertenece EL UNIVERSAL, es una red de medios lÃ­deres fundada en 1991, que promueve los valores democrÃ¡ticos, la prensa independiente y la libertad de expresiÃ³n en AmÃ©rica Latina a travÃ©s del periodismo de calidad para nuestras audiencias.

author: STERN.de
title: Arbeitskampf: Gewerkschaft verkÃ¼ndet Tarifeinigung bei DÃ¶nerfabrik Birtat
text:
Im Tarifkonflikt beim DÃ¶nerspieÃŸ-Hersteller Birtat gibt es eine Einigung - es ist zugleich nach Gewerkschaftsangaben der erste Tarifvertrag in der DÃ¶nerfleischindustrie. FÃ¼r die rund 120 BeschÃ¤ftigten wurde der Einstiegslohn auf 2.600 Euro festgelegt, wie die Gewerkschaft Nahrung-Genuss-GaststÃ¤tten (NGG) und das Unternehmen Meat World SE (Birtat) in Murr bei Ludwigsburg gemeinsam mitteilten. Ferner sei eine Anhebung der Entgelte in zwei Stufen im Gesamtumfang von bis zu 17 Prozent in der Spitze bei einer Laufzeit bis Ende 2026 vereinbart worden. FÃ¼r eine direkte Stellungnahme war das Unternehmen zunÃ¤chst nicht erreichbar.
Die Gewerkschaft NGG forderte eine ErhÃ¶hung der Entgelte um 375 Euro und einen Tarifvertrag. Bisher wurde die Arbeit an elf unterschiedlichen Tagen zeitweise niedergelegt. NGG-VerhandlungsfÃ¼hrerin Magdalena KrÃ¼ger sagte, dieser Tarifabschluss sei ein historisches Ergebnis in der DÃ¶nerfleischbranche und ein Erfolg der BeschÃ¤ftigten. Cihan Karaman, der Pressesprecher der Meat World SE erklÃ¤rte laut der gemeinsamen Mitteilung: "Wir sind Ã¼berzeugt, dass dieser Vertrag nicht nur Planungssicherheit schafft, sondern auch das Vertrauen und die Zusammenarbeit zwischen Unternehmen und BeschÃ¤ftigten stÃ¤rkt."
Birtat gehÃ¶rt zur Meat World SE und ist der NGG zufolge der grÃ¶ÃŸte Hersteller von DÃ¶nerspieÃŸen in Baden-WÃ¼rttemberg - und einer der fÃ¼hrenden Anbieter in Deutschland. In der Fabrik stecken die Mitarbeiterinnen und Mitarbeiter Fleisch vom Kalb, HÃ¤hnchen oder Rind auf SpieÃŸe - und geben dem Ganzen die traditionelle Form. Die SpieÃŸe werden dann schockgefrostet und ausgeliefert.

author: Josh Chilson
title: Noem defends decision to not deploy National Guard during flooding
text:
Noem defends decision to not deploy National Guard during flooding
Gov. Kristi Noemâ€™s office is defending her decision to not deploy the South Dakota National Guard during flood response efforts as state Democrats urge the governor to reconsider.
Noemâ€™s spokesperson Ian Fury sent a statement to media outlets Thursday saying some news reports tying the governorâ€™s decision to deployment costs are unfair to the governor.
Noem helped oversee the stateâ€™s response to widespread flooding across southeast South Dakota after
record-setting rain late last week.
During a media briefing the governor said deploying the National Guard is expensive. But Fury said cost wasnâ€™t the deciding factor.
Noem discussed her reasoning in
Tuesday's briefing, saying "we have to be wise with how we use our soldiers."
â€œIn order for the National Guard to be activated the county has to request it, and I make a decision if itâ€™s warranted, and if we should do that. We have not had to utilize the National Guard for this operation yet. Thatâ€™s usually, typically, a crisis situation," Noem said. "The National Guard is extremely expensive. And if you do activate the National Guard then the local county has to pay for it. They tend to be more expensive than using other resources or contractors, or things like that. That has not been necessary to this point, and I donâ€™t expect we will have to."
My heart goes out to the families on McCook Lake whose homes were destroyed by this flooding. Weâ€™ll keep doing everything we can to help with the situation.â€” Kristi Noem (@KristiNoem)
For right now, safety dictates that the public stay out of the area unless escorted by public safety officials. We areâ€¦
[pic.twitter.com/2X2KqG5FIU] [June 26, 2024]
The Republican governor said she talked with local leaders, and ultimately decided local officials, contractors and state agencies were â€œbest suited for the situation.â€
Furyâ€™s statement also noted National Guard soldiers face limitations in these situations, like being unable to enter peopleâ€™s homes or repair private property.
Meantime, state Democratic Party leaders issued a statement of their own Thursday calling for the governor to deploy the National Guard.
The statement pointed to Noem's
previous deployments of the National Guard to the U.S.-Mexico border, saying the guard was used as a "political statement."
"The National Guard's presence and assistance are crucial in providing relief and aiding in the rebuilding process," said Sioux Falls Democratic Sen. Liz Larson. "We urge Gov. Noem to act swiftly and decisively in deploying these essential resources to where they are needed most - right here in South Dakota."

author: Cate Charron; Indianapolis Business Journal
title: Ivy Tech to use $22M Lilly Endowment grant to boost early-ed workforce â€“ Inside INdiana Business
text:
Ivy Tech to use $22M Lilly Endowment grant to boost early-ed workforce
Subscriber Benefit
As a subscriber you can listen to articles at work, in the car, or while you work out.[Subscribe Now](https://www.insideindianabusiness.com/subscriptions/intropromo)
In an effort to grow the number of professionals working in early childhood education, the Lilly Endowment Inc. announced Thursday it is giving the Ivy Tech Foundation a $21.9 million grant to expand its offerings, including new micro-credentials, alternate associate degree pathways and an apprenticeship program.
The current Ivy Tech [early-childhood education program](https://www.ivytech.edu/programs/all-academic-programs/school-of-arts-sciences-education/education-early-childhood/), which currently offers short-term certificates, long-term certificates and associate degrees, is available at more than 16 of its locations.
The goal is to double the community collegeâ€™s early-childhood education programs by 2027, resulting in nearly 2,000 more graduates each year.
â€œAs Indianaâ€™s workforce engine, Ivy Tech has a responsibility to fuel the stateâ€™s pipeline of skilled early-childhood education talent,â€ Ivy Tech President Sue Ellspermann said in written remarks. â€œWe are grateful for the generous support from Lilly Endowment that is enabling us to remove barriers to education and training for early childhood educators.â€
An early-education associate curriculum can prepare Hoosiers for several job titles, such as a teacher, child care provider or nanny.
Indiana and the country at large are enduring widespread teacher and child care shortages. This grant is an attempt to remedy those gaps.
â€œAmong the most critical challenges facing early childhood education programs in Indiana are the recruiting, retaining and compensating of qualified teachers and caregivers,â€ said Ted Maple, Lilly Endowmentâ€™s vice president for education, in written remarks. â€œThough Ivy Tech cannot solve these challenges alone, we believe that its plan to expand and enhance training and education offerings has the potential to improve the quality of the early-childhood workforce in significant ways, ultimately to the benefit of thousands of young children in Indiana.â€
The three-year grant aims to make it easier for students to progress through their education. Similar to other programs, Ivy Tech will develop competency assessments to reward demonstrated on-the-job experience and identify where additional education is needed.
The college will also create new pathways for students to transfer into a bachelorâ€™s program once they complete their associateâ€™s degree. Leaders believe improving the stepping stone process will â€œon-rampâ€ students to K-12 careers after starting in early- childhood education.
Through partnerships with state agencies, Ivy Tech will start a federally-registered early-childhood education apprenticeship program to provide a â€œlearn and earnâ€ experience for working adults.
As the college develops new micro-credentials across its programs, it will do the same with early-childhood education. These smaller, often more targeted credentials are often added in addition to a studentâ€™s associateâ€™s degree or credential track.
Potential micro-credentials include child and youth growth and development; health, safety and nutrition; and family and community engagement.
Ivy Tech will also beef up its program marketing with a statewide campaign touting the new offerings.

author: GlobeNewswire
title: Ballad Health unveils three new Centers for Early Learning across Appalachian Highlands | User | theeveningleader.com
text:
JOHNSON CITY, Tenn., Feb. 29, 2024 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Young learners have new places to grow and thrive, as three new Ballad Health Centers for Early Learning open across the Appalachian Highlands of Northeast Tennessee and Southwest Virginia.
As viewers and listeners tuned in to the first day of the annual Niswonger Childrenâ€™s Network Radiothon, Ballad Health announced major steps towards fulfilling its commitment of opening up to 2,000 childcare slots across the region. New Centers for Early Learning in Greeneville, Tennessee; Lebanon, Virginia; and on the campus of East Tennessee State University are now open, with collective capacity to serve approximately 300 children. Each center serves Ballad Health team members and community members, and each accepts children who qualify for state childcare financial assistance in Tennessee and Virginia.
â€œWhen we launched the Ballad Health Niswonger Childrenâ€™s Network and our Strong Starts program, our intent was to integrate healthcare, education and community support and make the Appalachian Highlands the best place in the country to live, work and raise a family,â€ said Ballad Health Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Alan Levine. â€œHigh-quality childcare not only helps ensure children are ready to learn by the time they enter school, but it helps parents and other caregivers pursue their own education and work goals with confidence. This benefits not only our team members, but the larger community as well.â€
In an internal survey, Ballad Health team members emphasized that dependable childcare is a critical factor when choosing a place to live and work. To support this need, Ballad Healthâ€™s Board of Directors voted in early 2022 to invest up to $37 million to improve access to childcare by opening up to 11 new centers throughout the region, in addition to the current programs run by Ballad Health in Johnson City and Elizabethton, and a third run on the campus of Bristol Regional Medical Center by the YMCA of Bristol.
â€œWeâ€™re thrilled to open the first of our new childcare centers to begin serving families in our communities,â€ said Dr. Amy Doran, Ballad Healthâ€™s corporate director of early care and education. â€œTogether, we will work to ensure children are kindergarten-ready with a best-in-class curriculum that supports early literacy, numeracy and science skills, in addition to social and emotional development.â€
All Ballad Health Centers for Early Learning will be open five days a week, from 6 a.m. to 7 p.m., only closing on Thanksgiving and Christmas Day.
â€œChildren, especially infants, toddlers and preschoolers, learn through play. Itâ€™s key to their social, emotional and critical thinking abilities,â€ said Dr. Seth Brown, chief medical officer for the Niswonger Childrenâ€™s Network. â€œThe curriculum at our childcare centers ensures that children arenâ€™t just being looked after â€“ theyâ€™re being set up for a lifetime of learning and growing, which helps prepare them for a brighter future of better health.â€
Now open: The Centers for Early Learning in Greeneville, Tennessee, and Lebanon, Virginia
During the first day of the Radiothon, Ballad Health cut the ribbon on its Centers for Early Learning in Greeneville, Tennessee, and Lebanon, Virginia.
â€œItâ€™s been more than 10 years since we opened the doors of the first and only childrenâ€™s hospital here in the Appalachian Highlands. It was a landmark moment for the region, and we continue to see returns on that investment every single day,â€ said Scott Niswonger, a Greeneville resident and chief benefactor for Niswonger Childrenâ€™s Hospital and the Niswonger Childrenâ€™s Network.
â€œInvesting in childrenâ€™s well-being beyond the hospital is another milestone moment. The Ballad Health Strong Starts program, which supports families from birth to age 5, has thousands of participants region-wide, and the Strong Futures program here in Greenville supports hundreds of moms in addiction recovery and their children. Adding high-quality childcare to the mix locally is helping further wrap families in the type of support necessary for our children to learn and grow, and I am thrilled with Ballad Healthâ€™s continued commitment."
Located on the campus of Tusculum University, the Center for Early Learning in Greeneville features six classrooms bordering a common area, as well as a playground that includes innovative equipment to encourage imaginative play. At full capacity, 92 children, from infants to age 5, can be served.
In Lebanon, the Center for Early Learning is located less than three miles from Russell County Hospital, making it especially convenient for Ballad Health team members and their families. At full capacity, 70 children, from infants to age 5, can be served.
â€œPeople with young families are a huge part of our team, and theyâ€™re crucial to our ability to provide care,â€ said Greta Morrison, administrator and chief nursing officer of Russell County Hospital. â€œThe childcare crisis has a direct effect on the shortage of healthcare professionals and qualified professionals nationwide, and it is vital for everyone that there is adequate access to high quality childcare.â€
Ballad Health, East Tennessee State University unveil partnership to expand access to childcare and train future educators
The Ballad Health and East Tennessee State University (ETSU) partnership will enhance ETSUâ€™s current early childhood development curriculum, as students can complete their required observation hours at Ballad Healthâ€™s Centers for Early Learning, while developing hands-on experience under the guidance of licensed, experienced childcare professionals.
â€œETSU and Ballad health continue to partner to produce positive, generational change,â€ said Dr. Brian Noland, president of East Tennessee State University. â€œFrom the Strong BRAIN Institute â€“ which promotes the awareness of best practices and empirical study of Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACEs) â€“ to this newest childcare center on campus, where we will train the next generation of early childhood development professionals educating our children, our commitment to the region is always growing.â€
Once a licensing transfer is complete, ETSUâ€™s current childcare center will become part of the Ballad Health Centers for Early Learning, and it will be expanded accommodate significantly more children. The expanded center will continue to house current Little Bucs and Head Start students, while offering more childcare openings for team members of Ballad Health and ETSU, as well as community members. At full capacity, at least 133 children, from infants to age 5, can be served.
â€œEven with the addition of these centers, new centers slated to open in Norton, Kingsport and Abingdon later this year and Ballad Healthâ€™s future expansion efforts, the region still has a long way to go in terms of completely addressing the shortage of high-quality childcare,â€ Levine said. â€œWe believe this effort is a model of how employers, government and community organizations can partner to tackle this challenge.â€
Registration information
Families interested in enrolling their children in Ballad Healthâ€™s Early Learning Centers, or those who have questions, should fill out this form: https://redcap.link/ChildcareInterestForm or call 423-430-7632.
Radiothon continues to support local childrenâ€™s care
The Niswonger Childrenâ€™s Network Radiothon, which supports Niswonger Childrenâ€™s Hospital and the extension of other childrenâ€™s network services, continues on Friday, March 1, airing on 98.5 WTFM, 95.9 The Hog WRZK, Classic Hits 102.7 WVEK, and ESPN Tri-Cities from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. News Channel 11 anchors will also broadcast live from the event in the childrenâ€™s hospital lobby.
Interested donors can call 855-611-KIDS (5437) to make their pledges. Donations can also be accepted at any time by visiting www.niswongerchildrensradiothon.org or texting KITE to 24365.
For more information about the 2024 Niswonger Childrenâ€™s Hospital Radiothon, please visit www.niswongerchildrensradiothon.org or email tiffany.willis@balladhealth.org .
###
About Ballad Health:
Ballad Health is an integrated community health improvement organization serving 29 counties of the Appalachian Highlands in Northeast Tennessee, Southwest Virginia, Northwest North Carolina and Southeast Kentucky. Our system of 20 hospitals, post-acute care and behavioral health services, and a large multi-specialty group physician practice works closely with an active independent medical community and community stakeholders to improve the health and well-being of close to one million people. By leading in the adoption of value-based payments, addressing health-related social needs, funding clinical and health systems research and committing to long-term investments in strong children and families in our region, Ballad Health is striving to become a national model for rural health and healthcare. Learn more at www.BalladHealth.org .
About the Ballad Health Niswonger Childrenâ€™s Network:
The Ballad Health Niswonger Childrenâ€™s Network is a regional system of healthcare and community services marking a new phase in high standards of care and well-being for children, regardless of where they live across the Appalachian Highlands. The Ballad Health Niswonger Childrenâ€™s Network is comprised of physical assets, such as hospital and clinic locations, as well as community outreach programs and partnerships that advance childrenâ€™s health. It also represents Ballad Health and East Tennessee State Universityâ€™s commitment to expand pediatric services and specialties, along with a concerted regionwide effort to expand services for children beyond care when theyâ€™re sick or hospitalized.
Ashlea Ramey Ballad Health 423-863-2383 ashlea.ramey@balladhealth.org
